Award.AwardTitle: Travel Support for Students to Attend the 10th National Graduate Research Polymer Conference: May 21-24, 2012, Cleveland, Ohio
Award.AbstractNarration:
TECHNICAL AND NON-TECHNICAL SUMMARY:

This award provides partial travel support for graduate students to attend the National Graduate Research Polymer Conference to be held on May 21-24, 2012, at Case Western Reserve University in Cleveland.

The conference will offer the opportunity to about 200 students, as well as professors, researchers, and industry representatives from across the country to hear the latest research in the interdisciplinary polymer science and engineering field. There will be four plenary talks by distinguished leaders in the field. Specific symposia have been organized on bio-related polymers, energy-related materials, nanostructured materials, photonics and electronics, surfaces and interfaces, self-assembling polymers, as well as on structure, characterization, theory, and processing.

The major broader impact of this conference is the unique opportunity for the graduate students to stay current with the state-of-the-art research across the polymer frontiers and to promote fruitful interactions among all participants. Moreover, the conference will offer a panel discussion on career options for polymer/materials students, as well as a career fair to promote networking with company representatives.

Due to the exciting research and numerous breakthroughs that had occurred in those two years, the Case Western Reserve University (CWRU) Macromolecular Science and Engineering Department was compelled to host the 2012 NGRPC to allow students to share ideas and research results in a rapidly developing field. Summary From May 21 to May 24, 2012, CWRU hosted the 10th National Graduate Research Polymer Conference (NGRPC), the largest meeting for polymer graduate students in the nation. Nearly 100 students, professors, and researchers from across the country came to CWRU in Cleveland for three days to share research results, exchange ideas and nurture friendship. Students attended from top universities in states throughout the country, including Ohio, Michigan, Indiana, Iowa, South Carolina, Delaware, New York, Pennsylvania, Virginia, and Mississippi. Technical sessions spanned two days and were organized into important research areas: Energy, Biological Applications, Surfaces and Self Assembly, Characterization, and Nanostructured Materials. Additionally, students were also able to participate in a poster session that was well-received by all. Plenary addresses were given by some very prominent polymer scientists, including Prof. Eric Baer and Prof. Stuart Rowan of CWRU, Prof. Joseph DeSimone of UNC-Chapel Hill, and Dr. Barry Farmer of the Air Force Research Laboratory at Wright Patterson AFB. Dr. Michael Meador of the NASA Glenn Research Center facilitated a student discussion covering a range of topics, including career opportunities and polymer student chapters. In addition to the structured settings for academic growth, there were a number of opportunities for discussion, networking, and enjoyment. Breakfast and lunch were shared each day, as well as a barbecue on the first evening and a banquet on the last. Further, 35 students shared dormitories on the CWRU campus. There were numerous lively discussions and ideas shared amongst participants.
